title-group.article-title: Relation Between Mean Platelet Volume and Severity of Atherosclerosis in Patients With Acute Coronary Syndromes

abstract.p: Platelets play a central role in the pathophysiology of coronary artery disease (CAD). Increased mean platelet volume (MPV) is an indicator of platelet function and associated with poor clinical outcome in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS). We evaluated the relationship between MPV and severity of CAD in patients with ACS. A total of 395 patients with ACS were included. Severity of CAD was assessed with the Gensini and Syntax scores. High levels of MPV were associated with the Gensini and Syntax scores, number of diseased vessels (>50%), number of critical lesions (>50% and >70%), and noncritical lesions. After multivariate analysis, high levels of MPV were independent predictors of multivessel CAD together with age. In patients with ACS, high MPV levels were associated with severity of CAD. It is possible that MPV can be a helpful marker in patients with CAD for the severity of coronary atherosclerosis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Platelets play a central role in the pathophysiology of coronary artery disease (CAD). Large platelets are more active and have higher thrombotic potential. 1 Increased platelet activity is associated with atherosclerotic disease, including CAD. 2 Mean platelet volume (MPV) is a potentially useful marker of platelet activity. Mean platelet volume is associated with impaired angiographic reperfusion and poor clinical outcome in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS). 3 –5

Severity of coronary atherosclerosis is closely associated with cardiovascular prognosis in patients with ACS. 6 Therefore, prediction and diagnosis of severity of atherosclerosis is clinically relevant.
The aim of the current study was to evaluate the relationship between MPV and severity of CAD in ACS.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: A total of 520 consecutive patients with ACS undergoing coronary angiography were prospectively enrolled in the study. Patients with a history of prior myocardial infarction (MI), cerebrovascular event, peripheral arterial disease, percutaneous coronary intervention, coronary bypass surgery, and treatment with aspirin/clopidogrel/warfarin/unfractionated heparin and low-molecular-weight heparin were excluded. Finally, 395 patients were eligible to participate in the study. A high MPV was defined as a value ≥10.3 fl, 5,7 and the patients were divided into 2 groups—group 1 (low MPV) and group 2 (high MPV).

Three study groups were determined based on the diagnostic criteria of CAD, myocardial infarction with ST-segment elevation and non-ST-segment elevation (non-STEMI), and unstable angina pectoris (USAP). Informed consent was obtained from all patients. The study was approved by our local ethical committee. All demographic and clinical data were collected prospectively.

sec.title: Laboratory Analysis
sec.p: In all cases, blood samples were drawn at admission before starting any medication. We measured MPV in a blood sample collected in dipotassium ethylenedinitrotetraacetic acid tubes. All measurements were performed 30 minutes after blood collection by automatic blood counter (A Sysmex XE-2100, Symex, Kobe, Japan). The assessment of MPV was made without clopidogrel, heparin, or abciximab on board.

sec.title: Coronary Angiography
sec.p: Quantitative coronary angiography was performed by 2 experienced interventional cardiologists who had no knowledge of the patients’ clinical information. Gensini and Syntax scores were used to evaluate the severity of atherosclerosis. 8,9 For the Gensini score, the most severe stenosis in each of 8 coronary segments (left anterior descending artery, main diagonal branch, first septal perforator, left circumflex artery, obtuse marginal and posterolateral vessels, right coronary artery, and main descending branch) was graded from 1 to 4 (1%-49% lumen diameter reduction = 1 point, 50%-74% stenosis = 2, 75%-99% stenosis = 3, 100% occlusion = 4) to give a total score between 0 and 32. Syntax score was calculated with Syntax score calculator 2.1 (www.syntaxscore.com). The number of diseased vessels with >50% luminal stenosis was scored from 1 to 3 or more diseased vessels. Coronary stenotic lesions with >50% or >70% luminal stenosis were defined as critical lesions and with <50% luminal stenosis was defined as noncritical lesions.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: All analyses were performed using SPSS V 16.0 for windows (SPSS, Chicago, Illinois). Quantitative variables were expressed as mean ± standard deviation (SD) for parametric variables and as median and minimum–maximum levels for nonparametric variables. Comparison of parametric values between the 2 groups was performed by means of independent samples t test. Comparisons of nonparametric values between the 2 groups were performed by Mann-Whitney U test. Categorical variables were compared by the the chi-square test. Pearson test was used to test the correlation of parametric variables, and Spearman test was used to test the nonparametric variables. Differences among the number of diseased vessel groups were tested with 1-way analysis of variance (ANOVA). Multivariate logistic regression analysis was performed to assess the effects of the variables on multivessel disease. Multivariate linear regression analysis was performed to evaluate the effects of the variables on the Gensini score and Syntax score. A 2-tailed P < .05 was considered significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Demographic and clinical properties of patients in groups are shown in Table 1. Age, gender, smoking, diabetes, hypertension, and body mass index were similar in the 2 groups. Platelet count was significantly higher in group 1 than in group 2 (233 ± 64 × 106 vs 210 ± 51 × 106; P = .003). Mean platelet volume was 8.3 ± 0.9 in group 1 and 10.8 ± 0.4 in group 2 (P < .001). Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol was high in group 2 (P = .042) and triglyceride was high in group 1 (P = .001). Non-STEMI ratio was significantly higher in group 2 than in group 1 (48 [51.0%] vs 96 [31.8%]; P = .001). However, STEMI ratio was higher in group 1 than in group 2 (103 [34.2%] vs 18 [19.4%]; P = .006).

sec.p: The comparisons of angiographic properties of patients in the 2 groups are shown in Table 2. Gensini score was higher in group 2 than in group 1 (9.5 ± 4.4 vs 7.9 ± 4.0; P = .001), and Syntax score was higher in group 2 (16.1 ± 8.4 vs 13.9 ± 9.0; P = .016). Also, the number of diseased vessels (P = .013), number of critical lesions (>50% and 70%; P = .028 and P = .020, respectively), and number of noncritical lesions (P < .001) were higher in group 2. However, the number of lessions with total occlusion, left main disease and presence of classification and thrombus were not significant difference in 2 groups.

sec.p: A high MPV correlated with the Gensini and Syntax scores (r = .304, P < .001 and r = .314, P < .001, respectively; Figure 2), number of diseased vessels (P = .005), number of critical lesions (for >50% P = .028 and for >70% P = .020), and noncritical lesions (P < .001). Gensini score was associated with MPV (r = .304, P < .001), age (r = .192, P < .001), number of diseased vessel (r = .769, P < .001). Syntax score was significantly correlated with MPV (r = .314, P < .001), age (r = .192, P < .001), hemoglobin (r = −.145, P = .010), and glucose (r = .128, P < .001).

caption.p: Graph of relation between levels of MPV and Gensini and Syntax scores. MPV indicates mean platelet volume.

sec.p: After multivariate analysis, high MPV levels were independent predictors of multivessel CAD (odds ratio [OR]: 1.77, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.31-2.39; P < .001) together with age (OR: 1.04, 95% CI 1.00-1.07; P = .033). Multivariate linear regression analysis demonstrated that the increased MPV level was an independent risk factor for the Syntax and Gensini scores (b = .344, P < .001 and b = .311, P < .001, respectively) together with age (b = .212, P = .013 and b = .208, P = .009, respectively; Table 4).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: To our knowledge this is the first study that showed a positive relationship between high levels of MPV and severity of CAD in patients with ACS.

Platelets play a key role in the pathogenesis, morbidity, and mortality in ACS. 2,5,10 Elevated MPV has been proposed as a cardiovascular risk factor and has been recognized as an independent risk factor for myocardial infarction and adverse cardiovascular events such as recurrent ischemia or death. 11 –13 Several studies showed an association between MPV and CAD, stable angina pectoris, unstable angina pectoris, and acute MI. 3,5,11
–14 Several reports have also reported that MPV was associated with impaired myocardial perfusion and restenosis after primary coronary intervention. 5,13,15

Platelets with high MPV are metabolically and enzymatically more active and secrete more mediators. 16,17 These mediators can contribute to inflammation and atherogenesis and may explain an association between MPV and severity of coronary atherosclerosis. 18 Progression of atherosclerotic lesion was associated with chronic inflammation which was induced by platelets with chemotactic proteins, adhesion molecules, growth factors, inflammatory, and mitogenic factors. 17 Active platelets stimulate smooth muscle cell, and platelet-derived CD40 ligand, platelet factor 4 (PF4), and growth factors have been found in human atherosclerotic lesions. 11,17,19 In our study, patients with high MPV had high Gensini and Syntax scores and had more critical lesions. Therefore, an elevated MPV may indicate that patients with ACS had severe CAD and had a higher risk of acute coronary events due to increased platelet activation. So, high MPV may be useful for predicting high-risk patients.

Our study supports the hypothesis that platelet size may play a role in the severity of CAD. Although the physiopathogenesis of association between elevated MPV and severity of CAD is not completely understood, multiple mechanisms may be involved. The association between high MPV and severity of CAD could be explained by the increased number of both platelet leukocyte and platelet–platelet aggregation in coronary arterioles to cause microvascular injury. Chemotactic and mitogenic factors and CD40 ligands, which are expressed by activated platelets, may contribute to the extent and severity of coronary atherosclerosis. Perhaps, the extent and severity of CAD may cause increasing production of platelets with high MPV, and these larger platelets may aggregates to form plaques and contribute to the initiation of ACS.

Previous studies reported different results regarding the relation between MPV and severity of atherosclerosis. De Luca et al measured MPV in 1411 consecutive patients undergoing coronary angiography and showed that MPV is not related to the extent of CAD. 20 Tavil et al measured MPV in 205 consecutive patients with metabolic syndrome who underwent coronary angiography and did not observe any difference in MPV among patients with or without significant CAD (patients with >50% stenosis). 21 Ihara et al reported that MPV showed lower values in the angiographically positive patients than angiographically negative patients. 22 Our study showed for the first time a positive association between MPV and severity of CAD by Gensini and Syntax scores. Studies mentioned above did not use Gensini or Syntax scores and only one of them used extent of CAD.

Investigators showed that platelet volume was positively associated with increased megakaryocyte ploidy and negatively associated with number of megakaryocyte. 5,23 Furthermore, several studies demonstrated a significant association between MPV and cardiovascular events, even after adjusting for platelet count. 5,11 In accordance with previous studies, we observed that MPV was inversely correlated with the total platelet count (P = .003). A similar relationship was also observed by others. 24

Previous reports showed that there is a close relationship between MPV and other prognostic factors, such as smoking, diabetes, obesity, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. 25
–28 But we do not have clear information about an association between MPV and known ischemic heart disease risk factors, so an elevated MPV may contribute to adverse events through a novel mechanism. We did not find any association between MPV and smoking, diabetes, hypertension, or gender. We observed that advanced age and severity of CAD were significantly associated with larger platelets.

Finally, different methods can be used to assess platelet activation (eg, flow cytometry, optical aggregometry, platelet reactivity tests, or platelet aggregate ratio). 29 All tests have limitations such as complex preanalytic factors, reduced specificity, and poor reproducibility. However, MPV is a marker, not requiring advanced or expensive technology.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: High MPV seems to be an independent risk factor for CAD and correlated with the severity of the coronary atherosclerosis. This is a simple, reliable, and economical method that indicates platelet activation and predicts the risk of ACS and coronary atherosclerosis. We suggest that MPV can be added to the conventional risk factors for CAD.
